questions.text: An 82-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son because he is concerned about her forgetfulness for the past 2 years. She occasionally walks into a room and forgets why she went there and often forgets where she left her keys. She is sometimes unable to recall a familiar individual's name. She reports that she has become slower at completing sudoku puzzles. She has been living independently since the death of her husband 3 years ago. She goes shopping, cooks her own meals, and plays bridge with her friends every weekend. She is not anxious about her memory lapses. She has no trouble sleeping but has been getting up earlier than she used to. She has hypertension that is managed with hydrochlorothiazide. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows a normal gait. She describes her mood as “good” and her speech is normal. Her thought process is organized and her judgment is intact. She makes one error when performing serial sevens. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Mild memory impairment, occasional difficulties in word finding, and slower cognitive processing are normal effects of aging. An important distinguishing factor between normal aging and forms of dementia is the degree to which independence with everyday activities is impaired. In normal aging, independence in daily activities is preserved. Because this patient lives independently and her cognitive exams are within normal limits, dementia is unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with Alzheimer disease present with progressive cognitive decline that can manifest with short term memory loss. Often, patients are unaware of their difficulties and relatives may express concern before the patient does. While this patient does have a lack of concern over her memory loss, her daily life is largely unaffected. Moreover, the cognitive dysfunction in Alzheimer disease is often accompanied by behavioral changes (such as aggression, depression, insomnia), which are absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Pseudodementia is associated with other psychiatric disorders (especially depression) in which cognitive deficits such as memory loss are seen after the onset of mood symptoms. This patient reports her mood is “good” and the history reveals no symptoms such as anhedonia, changes in appetite, psychomotor agitation, or suicidal ideation that would suggest depression.

D) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) presents with changes in personality and behavior (e.g., apathy), especially inappropriate social behavior in early stages (e.g., disinhibition), which this 82-year-old woman does not show. Additionally, the onset of FTD usually occurs in middle-aged individuals (40–60 years).

E) INCORRECT:

While memory loss is a symptom of Lewy-body dementia, it presents with neurocognitive decline over the course of 8–10 years, beginning with deficits in attention and executive functioning early and memory loss later in the course of disease. Patients may experience visual hallucinations and parkinsonian motor disorders (e.g., shuffling gait, rigidity of movements), which this patient lacks.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with vascular dementia will present with a stepwise decline in cognitive and neurological function causing interference with independence in everyday activities. This patient has a risk factor for cerebrovascular disease (hypertension), but the minor memory loss in this patient is not consistent with the degree of cognitive impairment seen in vascular dementia. Moreover, cognitive impairment is often associated with other focal neurological deficits (e.g., hemiparesis, urinary incontinence, gait disturbance), which are absent in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

The degree of cognitive decline in normal pressure hydrocephalus is generally more severe than the minor memory loss seen in this patient. Normal pressure hydrocephalus presents with the classic triad of “wet, wobbly, and wacky” (urinary incontinence, gait disorder, and dementia), which this patient lacks.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).
questions.hint: These cognitive defects have not interfered with independence in everyday activities of this individual's life.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for an annual physical examination. He reports that his vision has progressively improved over the past 6 months and he no longer needs the glasses he used while driving. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include glyburide, hydrochlorothiazide, and enalapril. Examination shows 20/20 vision bilaterally. Fundoscopy shows a few microaneurysms of retinal vessels. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's improved vision?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased susceptibility to glare can be seen in darker colored eyes compared to lighter colored ones. However, it is an unlikely pathology. Increased susceptibility to glare is a finding of normal aging, most likely due to the effects of intraocular light scatter. It is increased in patients with cataract and would not present with an improvement in myopia in middle age.

B) CORRECT:

Denaturation of lens proteins leads to the loss of lens elasticity seen in presbyopia, a classic condition associated with aging. This patient is experiencing the phenomenon of “second sight,” in which presbyopia corrects a long-standing case of myopia, resulting in improved visual acuity due to lens changes.

C) INCORRECT:

Liquefication of the vitreous humor is a physiological aging process that leads to condensing and shrinking of the gel-like substance. The vitreous membrane can eventually detach from the retina (posterior vitreous detachment). However, this would cause a worsening in the patient's vision (e.g., floaters, photopsia, scotoma), not an improvement.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased ciliary muscle tone is a mechanism that causes decreased diameter of the ciliary muscle, leading to constriction and accommodation of the pupil. It also induces opening of the trabecular meshwork and drainage of aqueous humor. It would be a mechanism for decreasing intraocular pressure in an ocular emergency like glaucoma, but it would not improve myopia during middle age. Furthermore, ciliary muscle tone tends to decrease with aging.

E) INCORRECT:

Macular degeneration is classified into two major forms: dry and wet macular degeneration. Dry macular degeneration is caused by the deposition of drusen under the retinal pigment epithelium, and wet macular degeneration is associated with neovascularization in the subretinal space. Both conditions cause decreased visual acuity, scotomas, and eventually blindness. However, since these conditions lead to progressively worsening central visual impairment in old age, they would not present with increasing visual acuity in middle age, as seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's improvement in vision is likely due to presbyopia.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing wrinkles on her face and sagging skin. She says that her skin used to be smooth and firm. Examination shows diffuse xerosis and mild atrophy, laxity, and fine wrinkles on the periorbital skin. Which of the following processes is most likely involved in the development of this patient's skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lysyl oxidase activity does not change with aging. In fact, lysyl oxidase activity may even increase because cross-linked collagen is more stable in older skin than younger skin. This may be partly responsible for the toughness of older skin.

B) INCORRECT:

Collagen biosynthesis decreases rather than increases as skin ages. Simultaneously, collagen becomes disorganized. These changes are thought to be key factors in the overall decrease in skin strength and propensity to form wrinkles observed in aged skin.

C) CORRECT:

Chronological aging of the skin, in particular of the dermis, is due in large part to the decreased assembly of elastin fibers. This accounts for increased skin laxity and rigidity. Atrophy of the dermis due to loss of collagen and volume deficit as a result of reduced glycosaminoglycan synthesis further contribute to the appearance of chronologically aged skin. Moreover, aging skin is prone to xerosis secondary to moisture loss resulting from diminished lipid and sebum production at the surface.

D) INCORRECT:

Age-related decrease of fibroblast activity contributes in large parts to the appearance of chronologically aged skin, as fibroblast synthesize collagens and components of the extracellular matrix, such as glycosaminoglycans (e.g., hyaluronic acid). Since GAGs maintain skin structure and moisture, decreased synthesis results in loss of volume and hydration, as well as the development of wrinkles and folds. Moreover, a decrease in fibroblast activity contributes to delayed wound healing.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased lipofuscin deposits in organs such as heart, colon, and eyes can be found in elderly persons as a sign of normal aging. Lipofuscin is also implicated in the pigmentation changes seen in aging skin. However, it is not known to contribute to structural changes in aging skin, such as sagging and wrinkles.

F) INCORRECT:

The crosslinking rate of collagen fibrils typically remains unchanged or increases slightly in older individuals. This is because the activity and abundance of the enzyme responsible for catalyzing collagen and elastin crosslinking remain relatively constant with time.
questions.hint: This woman has normal, age-related changes of the skin.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine examination. She has a history of hypertension well-controlled with diet and exercise. She has no history of smoking or illicit drug use. She walks one mile daily. Her pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 119/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following age-related changes in respiratory function is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Increased lung compliance is commonly found in individuals of advanced age due to loss of elastic fibers. Chest wall compliance typically decreases because of increased chest wall stiffness. Stiffening of the chest wall and loss of elastic recoil impair lung emptying during expiration, which results in increased residual volume. When compared to a healthy young adult, individuals of advanced age have increased alveolar dead space and V/Q mismatch due to age-related loss of lung surface area. Moreover, while aging classically leads to a decrease in FEV1 and vital capacity, total lung capacity usually remains unchanged.

Other age-related changes include decreased respiratory muscle strength (which can hinder effective coughing and increase the risk of aspiration and infection) and impaired ventilatory response to hypercapnia and hypoxia.

B) INCORRECT:

Vital capacity (VC = tidal volume + IRV + ERV) commonly decreases (not increases) with advanced age. This is primarily due to loss of elastic recoil and stiffening of the chest wall.

C) INCORRECT:

Residual volume can be decreased in restrictive lung disease. With advanced age, residual volume classically increases (not decreases) due to loss of elastic recoil and increased chest wall stiffening.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased total lung capacity (TLC = vital capacity + residual volume) is classically seen in patients with restrictive lung disease. While normal aging is associated with an overall decrease in lung function, TLC will remain constant in the absence of respiratory disease.

E) INCORRECT:

In advanced age, age-related calcification of the chest wall and osteoporosis-mediated kyphosis lead to increased chest wall stiffness and decreased expansion of the thoracic cage during inspiration. Therefore, chest wall compliance classically decreases (not increases) with age.

F) INCORRECT:

The alveolar-arterial gradient (A-a gradient) compares the oxygenation status of alveoli and arterial blood. In advanced age, age-related loss of lung surface area increases alveolar dead space and V/Q mismatch. Increased V/Q mismatch results in hypoxia (↓ PaO2), causing an increase (not decrease) in the A-a gradient.
questions.hint: The patient lacks any history of respiratory disease and has a normal physical examination. Therefore, her change in respiratory function is likely a consequence of normal aging.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to the physician because of decreased sexual performance for the past 2 years. He reports that it takes longer for his penis to become erect, and he cannot maintain an erection for as long as before. His ejaculations have become less forceful. Once he has achieved an orgasm, he requires several hours before he can have another orgasm. He has been happily married for 40 years and he has no marital conflicts. His only medication is esomeprazole for gastroesophageal reflux disease. Examination shows coarse dark pubic and axillary hair. The skin of his lower extremity is warm to the touch; pedal pulses and sensation are intact. Rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged prostate with no masses. His fasting serum glucose is 96 mg/dL and his prostate-specific antigen is 3.9 ng/mL (N < 4). Which of the following etiologies is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction can be a manifestation of underlying vascular disease, often associated with conditions such as hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and peripheral artery disease. This patient's medical history and physical examination (warm lower extremities, intact pedal pulses and sensation) are not suggestive of a vascular etiology of his condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction can be caused by various classes of medications such as antihypertensives (e.g., beta-blockers, thiazide diuretics), antidepressants (e.g., SSRIs), and dopamine antagonists (e.g., antipsychotics). The patient is currently treated with esomeprazole, which is not associated with erectile dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

Psychogenic erectile dysfunction may develop due to psychosocial stress (e.g., relationship trouble, trauma) or in association with an underlying psychiatric condition (e.g., depression, anxiety disorder). However, this patient does not report any marital conflicts nor does he demonstrate any symptoms of a psychiatric condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Prostate cancer is not a direct cause of erectile dysfunction, but treatment for this condition can lead to erectile dysfunction through the use of antiandrogen therapy or as a result of surgical excision. This patient's physical examination shows symmetrical growth of the prostate with no masses and normal prostate-specific antigen, which is consistent with benign prostatic hyperplasia.

E) INCORRECT:

Neurogenic causes of erectile dysfunction (ED) include stroke, trauma that affects the brain and/or spinal cord, and neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., multiple sclerosis, Parkinson disease), none of which are seen in this patient. Patients with neurogenic ED typically cannot develop erections. While this man is having difficulty obtaining and maintaining his erection, he is still able to develop an erection.

F) CORRECT:

Physiologic changes in male sexual function due to aging include delays in obtaining and maintaining an erection, longer refractory period between orgasms, and decreased ejaculate force and volume, which this patient describes. These are normal changes that progress gradually with advancing age, and they are not reflective of hormonal changes or decreased sexual desire.
questions.hint: Laboratory testing would reveal a normal testosterone level and decreased sperm production.

questions.text: An 81-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She lives in a senior living facility in the Midwestern United States. There have been several cases of heavy metal poisoning through drinking water in her state, and she is concerned about potential exposure to toxic substances. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 153 cm (5 ft 0 in) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Pulse is 76/min and regular, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Which of the following neurologic examination findings in this patient would necessitate immediate investigation?

choices.text: Decreased vibration sensation in the great toe

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-frequency, progressive, bilateral hearing loss in an older patient suggests presbycusis, which affects more than 50% of individuals at the age of 75 years, with increasing prevalence in older age groups. This condition is caused by age-related damage to hair cells at the base of the cochlea. Although otoscopy and audiometry would eventually be indicated to establish the diagnosis, high-frequency hearing loss is an expected finding in older patients and does not require immediate investigation.

B) CORRECT:

Vertical or rotatory nystagmus on neurologic examination is considered abnormal in all age groups and warrants immediate investigation. Causes for vertical nystagmus include vestibular conditions (e.g., anterior and posterior semicircular canal BPPV), severe alcohol intoxication, drug side effects (e.g., phencyclidine, lithium, carbamazepine, phenytoin), Wernicke encephalopathy, and CNS lesions (e.g., bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia in multiple sclerosis, cerebellar lesions). In contrast, although horizontal nystagmus is most frequently pathological, it can occur physiologically (e.g., end-gaze nystagmus) in all age groups. Other neurophthalmological findings considered normal in older patients (especially those aged over 80 years) are sluggish convergence, sluggish pupillary reflex, decreased upward gaze (while lateral and downward movements usually remain intact), and impaired accommodation (presbyopia).
Image Description:

In jerk nystagmus, there is a slow drift phase followed by a fast corrective phase. The name of the nystagmus is determined by the direction of movement in the fast phase (left horizontal, right horizontal, downbeat, upbeat, clockwise, or counterclockwise).

C) INCORRECT:

A decreased sensation of vibration in the distal lower extremities is common in older patients. It can be attributed to the age-related degeneration of distal sensory axons and does not require immediate investigation if it is an isolated finding. Further diagnostic workup is indicated if the decreased sensation of vibration occurs alongside additional signs and symptoms (e.g., signs of ischemia, ulcers, loss of reflexes, concomitant involvement of upper extremities, changes to other types of sensation).

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased sense of smell (hyposmia) is a common finding in older patients, affecting more than 60% of individuals aged ≥ 80 years. This finding can be attributed to the age-related degeneration of olfactory neurons. The isolated finding of hyposmia/anosmia in an older patient does not require immediate investigation. Hyposmia in patients < 60 years of age should raise concern for an underlying disease (e.g., Parkinson disease) and further diagnostic workup might be indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Diminished or absent ankle jerk reflexes are a common finding in older patients. This finding can be attributed to the age-related degeneration of distal sensory axons, which results in diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes. The isolated finding of absent ankle jerk reflexes in an older patient does not require immediate investigation. Further diagnostic workup is indicated if this finding occurs with additional signs and symptoms, e.g., muscle weakness, sensory changes, constitutional symptoms, asymmetry, back pain.
questions.hint: This finding can be observed on examination of the cranial nerves.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He feels well. Following the recent death of his wife, he moved in with his daughter. He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He is physically active and exercises three to four times weekly. His medications include lisinopril, metoprolol, atorvastatin, and aspirin. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (177 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows ecchymoses on the dorsal aspect of the patient's forearms bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 205,000/mm3, a prothrombin time of 12 seconds, activated partial thromboplastin time of 30 seconds, and a bleeding time of 3 minutes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's physical examination findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aspirin use increases the risk of bleeding, bleeding time, and bruising, which typically manifest as ecchymoses after minor trauma (most commonly on the lower extremities). While this patient has bilateral ecchymoses on the dorsal forearms, it was not preceded by any trauma. The absence of prior trauma and this patient's normal bleeding time make aspirin use an unlikely explanation for his symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Senile purpura is a benign skin condition that typically affects individuals aged > 50 years and manifests with recurrent, irregularly-shaped, dark purple macules. It is caused by progressive loss of dermal connective tissue, subcutaneous fat, and blood vessel elasticity with age, all of which results in increased susceptibility to bruising in elderly individuals. Senile purpura is more common in light-skinned persons (due to increased sensitivity to sunlight) and typically develops on sun-exposed areas (e.g., forearms, face, neck). The diagnosis is clinical and does not require further evaluation.
Image Description:

Forearm of an elderly patient

There are multiple irregular dark purple macules with well-defined margins. The surrounding skin appears thin and inelastic.

C) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) can develop in a patient aged > 55 years and manifest with ecchymoses. However, ITP is characterized by a low platelet count (< 100,000/mm3). This patient's normal platelet count is inconsistent with ITP.

D) INCORRECT:

Nutrient deficiency (e.g., protein malnutrition, vitamin K or vitamin C deficiency) can increase an individual's risk of bleeding and bruising and manifest with ecchymoses. However, nutrient deficiency typically develops in individuals who are chronically ill, have limited access to food, or have malabsorption diseases (e.g., pancreatic insufficiency, celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease), none of which apply to this man.

E) INCORRECT:

Physical abuse is a potential cause of bruising in an elderly individual with a normal coagulation profile. However, most elderly individuals who experience physical abuse present with asymmetric skin lesions in unusual locations, unexplained fractures, signs of malnutrition, depressed mood, and, in rare cases, suicidality. This patient's isolated bruising and the symmetric bilateral ecchymoses on the dorsal forearms make another etiology more likely.
questions.hint: Other findings associated with this patient's presentation include presbyopia, occasional word-finding difficulty, and bilateral hearing loss.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 78 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: routine health maintenance examination
History of Present Illness:

patient brought by son
feels well

Past Medical History:

10-year history of hypertension
hyperlipidemia
mild angina

Medications:

losartan
pravastatin
nitroglycerin

Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History
noncontributory
Psychosocial History:

lives in a retirement community
enjoys active living

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


37.0°C(98.6°F)
80/min
17/min
140/86 mm Hg
-

165 cm(5 ft 5 in)

70 kg(154 lb)
26 kg/m2



Appearance: no acute distress
Skin: multiple 1–3 cm macules; located on the neck and the dorsal aspect of hands and forearms; nontender and nonpruritic; a photograph of the lesions is shown
HEENT: funduscopic shows grade 2/4 arteriovenous nicking; normal conjunctivae and oropharynx; thyroid gland is normal in size with no mass or tenderness
Neck: no jugular venous distention
Pulmonary: clear lung fields
Cardiac: regular rhythm; S1 and S2, with an early systolic murmur
Abdominal: soft and nontender; liver and spleen cannot be palpated

Diagnostic Studies


Blood



Platelet count:
185,000/mm3



Prothrombin time:
12 seconds


Activated partial thromboplastin time:
30 seconds



Without treatment, which of the following is the most likely clinical course of this patient’s existing skin lesions?

choices.text: Slow increase in size and ulceration
Rapid increase in number and spread to the trunk

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This clinical course can occur with blistering skin disorders (e.g., pemphigus vulgaris, bullous pemphigoid, Steven Johnson syndrome) and pyogenic granuloma. Senile purpura lesions do not generally enlarge or ulcerate.

B) INCORRECT:

Certain viral exanthems (e.g., varicella, measles, rubella) and noninfectious skin diseases (e.g., erythema multiforme) can start in the extremities and spread rapidly to the trunk. New senile purpura can appear over time but the existing lesions do not increase in number rapidly. Moreover, senile purpura typically develops in the face, neck, and dorsal aspects of extremities rather than the trunk.

C) INCORRECT:

Senile purpura are not premalignant skin lesions. Examples of premalignant skin conditions include actinic keratosis and dysplastic nevi, both of which can occur in sun-exposed areas such as the neck and the dorsal surface of the hands and forearms. Actinic keratosis, however, appears as brownish papules or plaques (rather than macules) with fine white scaling of the overlying skin, and the lesions are typically less than 1 cm in size. Dysplastic nevi can have an irregular shape but would be expected to have poorly defined margins and variations in color.

D) CORRECT:

Senile purpura, which is a common benign dermatological condition among older individuals, manifests as dark purple macules with irregular edges in sun-exposed areas (e.g., face, neck, dorsal aspect of hands and forearms). The lesions are a result of damage to dermal connective tissues and blood vessels due to aging and chronic sun exposure causing blood vessels to rupture easily, resulting in purpura or ecchymoses. Senile purpura can recur but the existing lesions will resolve spontaneously over a few weeks without treatment. In some cases, mild brownish discoloration may persist as a result of hemosiderin deposition.

E) INCORRECT:

These characteristics are not features of senile purpura and apply to conditions such as tinea versicolor and leprosy. Senile purpura typically resolves with brownish discoloration or without any permanent discoloration.
questions.hint: This patient's uniformly dark purple skin lesions with an irregular shape but well-defined margins are most likely senile purpura.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the office for an annual physical examination. He reports that his vision has progressively improved over the past 6 months and he no longer needs the glasses he used while driving. Examination shows 20/20 vision bilaterally. Fundoscopy shows a few microaneurysms of retinal vessels. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's improved vision?

A) INCORRECT:

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman is brought to the office by her son because he is concerned about her forgetfulness for the past 2 years. She occasionally walks into a room and forgets why she went there and often forgets where she left her keys. She is sometimes unable to recall a familiar individual's name. She lives independently and goes shopping, cooks her own meals, and plays bridge with her friends every weekend. She has hypertension that is managed with hydrochlorothiazide. Examination shows a normal gait. She describes her mood as “good”; her thought process is organized and her judgment is intact. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Mild memory impairment, occasional difficulties in word finding, and slower cognitive processing are normal effects of aging. An important distinguishing factor between normal aging and forms of dementia is the degree to which independence with everyday activities is impaired. In normal aging, independence in daily activities is preserved. Because this patient lives independently and her cognitive exams are within normal limits, dementia is unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with Alzheimer disease present with progressive cognitive decline that can manifest with short term memory loss. Often, patients are unaware of their difficulties and relatives may express concern before the patient does. While this patient's son does express concern over her memory loss, her daily life is largely unaffected. Moreover, the cognitive dysfunction in Alzheimer disease is often accompanied by behavioral changes (such as aggression, depression, insomnia), which are absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) presents with changes in personality and behavior (e.g., apathy), especially inappropriate social behavior in early stages (e.g., disinhibition), which this 82-year-old woman does not show. Additionally, the onset of FTD usually occurs in middle-aged individuals (40–60 years).

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with vascular dementia will present with a stepwise decline in cognitive and neurological function causing interference with independence in everyday activities. This patient has a risk factor for cerebrovascular disease (hypertension), but the minor memory loss in this patient is not consistent with the degree of cognitive impairment seen in vascular dementia. Moreover, cognitive impairment is often associated with other focal neurological deficits (e.g., hemiparesis, urinary incontinence, gait disturbance), which are absent in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

The degree of cognitive decline in normal pressure hydrocephalus is generally more severe than the minor memory loss seen in this patient. Normal pressure hydrocephalus presents with the classic triad of “wet, wobbly, and wacky” (urinary incontinence, gait disorder, and dementia), which this patient lacks.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).
questions.hint: These cognitive defects have not interfered with independence in everyday activities of this individual's life.

questions.text: An 81-year-old woman comes to your clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. She lives in a senior living facility in Yellowknife, Northwest Territories. She is concerned about possible exposure to toxic substances due to several recent cases of heavy metal poisoning through drinking water in her territory. Her medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her medications are lisinopril and atorvastatin. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 153 cm tall and weighs 60 kg; BMI is 26. Pulse is 76/min and regular, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Which one of the following neurologic examination findings in this patient would necessitate immediate investigation?

choices.text: Decreased vibration sensation in the great toe.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diminished or absent ankle jerk reflexes are a common finding in older patients. This finding can be attributed to the age-related degeneration of distal sensory axons, which results in diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes. The isolated finding of absent ankle jerk reflexes in an older patient does not require immediate investigation. Further diagnostic workup is indicated if this finding occurs with additional signs and symptoms, e.g., muscle weakness, sensory changes, constitutional symptoms, asymmetry, back pain.

B) INCORRECT:

A decreased sensation of vibration in the distal lower extremities is common in older patients. It can be attributed to the age-related degeneration of distal sensory axons and does not require immediate investigation if it is an isolated finding. Further diagnostic workup is indicated if the decreased sensation of vibration occurs alongside additional signs and symptoms (e.g., signs of ischemia, ulcers, loss of reflexes, concomitant involvement of upper extremities, changes to other types of sensation).

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased sense of smell (hyposmia) is a common finding in older patients, affecting more than 60% of individuals aged ≥ 80 years. This finding can be attributed to the age-related degeneration of olfactory neurons. The isolated finding of hyposmia/anosmia in an older patient does not require immediate investigation. Hyposmia in patients < 60 years of age should raise concern for an underlying disease (e.g., Parkinson disease) and further diagnostic workup might be indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

High-frequency, progressive, bilateral hearing loss in an older patient suggests presbycusis, which affects more than 50% of individuals at the age of 75 years, with increasing prevalence in older age groups. This condition is caused by age-related damage to hair cells at the base of the cochlea. Although otoscopy and audiometry would eventually be indicated to establish the diagnosis, high-frequency hearing loss is an expected finding in older patients and does not require immediate investigation.

E) CORRECT:

Vertical or rotatory nystagmus on neurologic examination is considered abnormal in all age groups and warrants immediate investigation. Causes for vertical nystagmus include vestibular conditions (e.g., anterior and posterior semicircular canal BPPV), severe alcohol intoxication, drug side effects (e.g., phencyclidine, lithium, carbamazepine, phenytoin), Wernicke encephalopathy, and CNS lesions (e.g., bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia in multiple sclerosis, cerebellar lesions). In contrast, although horizontal nystagmus is most frequently pathological, it can occur physiologically (e.g., end-gaze nystagmus) in all age groups. Other neurophthalmological findings considered normal in older patients (especially those aged over 80 years) are sluggish convergence, sluggish pupillary reflex, decreased upward gaze (while lateral and downward movements usually remain intact), and impaired accommodation (presbyopia).

Key learning point: Vertical nystagmus is always abnormal and requires immediate investigation, as it may indicate serious central nervous system or vestibular pathology.
Image Description:

In jerk nystagmus, there is a slow drift phase followed by a fast corrective phase. The name of the nystagmus is determined by the direction of movement in the fast phase (left horizontal, right horizontal, downbeat, upbeat, clockwise, or counterclockwise).
questions.hint: This finding can be observed on examination of the cranial nerves.

questions.text: You are seeing an 82-year-old woman who is brought to your clinic by her son due to concerns about her forgetfulness over the past 2 years. She reports occasionally walking into a room and forgetting why she went there, often misplacing her keys, and sometimes being unable to recall the name of a familiar person. She lives independently, does her own shopping and cooking, and plays bridge with friends every weekend. Her hypertension is managed with hydrochlorothiazide. On examination, her gait is normal. She describes her mood as “good,” her thought process is organized, and her judgment is intact. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) presents with changes in personality and behavior (e.g., apathy), especially inappropriate social behavior in early stages (e.g., disinhibition), which this 82-year-old woman does not show. Additionally, the onset of FTD usually occurs in middle-aged individuals (40–60 years).

B) INCORRECT:

The degree of cognitive decline in normal pressure hydrocephalus is generally more severe than the minor memory loss seen in this patient. Normal pressure hydrocephalus presents with the classic triad of “wet, wobbly, and wacky” (urinary incontinence, gait disorder, and dementia), which this patient lacks.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with Alzheimer disease present with progressive cognitive decline that can manifest with short term memory loss. Often, patients are unaware of their difficulties and relatives may express concern before the patient does. While this patient's son does express concern over her memory loss, her daily life is largely unaffected. Moreover, the cognitive dysfunction in Alzheimer disease is often accompanied by behavioral changes (such as aggression, depression, insomnia), which are absent in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Mild memory impairment, occasional difficulties in word finding, and slower cognitive processing are normal effects of aging. An important distinguishing factor between normal aging and forms of dementia is the degree to which independence with everyday activities is impaired. In normal aging, independence in daily activities is preserved. Because this patient lives independently and her cognitive exams are within normal limits, dementia is unlikely.

Key learning point: Mild forgetfulness and slower cognitive processing with preserved daily functioning are normal effects of aging, not indicative of dementia.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with vascular dementia will present with a stepwise decline in cognitive and neurological function causing interference with independence in everyday activities. This patient has a risk factor for cerebrovascular disease (hypertension), but the minor memory loss in this patient is not consistent with the degree of cognitive impairment seen in vascular dementia. Moreover, cognitive impairment is often associated with other focal neurological deficits (e.g., hemiparesis, urinary incontinence, gait disturbance), which are absent in this patient.
questions.hint: These cognitive defects have not interfered with independence in everyday activities of this individual's life.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He takes no medications. Physical examination and laboratory studies show no abnormalities. Compared to a healthy adolescent, this patient is most likely to have which of the following changes in immune function?

choices.text: Increased number of circulating B cells
Increased antibody affinity for foreign antigens

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

With increasing age, autoimmunity is increased rather than decreased because the synthesis of Treg cells decreases and the synthesis of autoantibodies increases.

B) INCORRECT:

The phagocytic ability of neutrophils is decreased in older individuals, but the number of circulating neutrophils or neutrophil precursors are not affected by aging.

C) CORRECT:

With advancing age, the ability of the body to mount antibody and cell-mediated immune responses to a new antigen decreases. This is caused by a decline in the counts of most subsets of B cells and T cells. The decreased immune response is also caused by impaired affinity maturation and V(D)J recombination, an increase in the proportion of monoclonal cell lines, and decreased affinity of antibodies for new antigens due to a decrease in the variety of B-cell receptors for antigens. These changes lead to an increased need for booster vaccinations in older adults.

D) INCORRECT:

The number of circulating B cells as well as the number of B-cell precursors decreases with advanced age because of senescence-related alterations in the microenvironment of the bone marrow and impaired responsiveness to growth-stimulating cytokines.

E) INCORRECT:

The affinity of antibodies for antigens decreases rather than increases with age. This is primarily because of impaired affinity maturation, impaired V(D)J recombination, a decrease in the variety of B-cell receptors, and an increase in the proportion of monoclonal cell lines.

F) INCORRECT:

In older individuals, the amount of complement protein produced by the liver is less when compared to younger individuals.
questions.hint: Age is associated with physiologic changes in certain immune functions, including a decrease in CD4+ T-cell numbers.
